anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3  2  of the Act it was competent to the Government to fix  a  a minimum rate of wages for time work  called a minimum time rate ,  b  a minimum rate of wages for piece work  called a minimum piece rate   or  c  a minimum rate to be applied in the case of employees employed on piece work for the purpose of securing to such, employees a minimum rate of wages on a time work basis  called a guaranteed time rate-  and what was done by the Government was to fix a minimum time rate within the meaning of s. 3 2   a

anchor.surface_text: The matters do not come to us by way of appeal directly from the orders of the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar. They were the subject, in the first instance, of proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Assam. Proceedings by way of certiorari are not of course .  Vide Halsburys Laws of England,

concepts.interpretation: Supervisory jurisdiction, not appellate; High Court could refuse if no failure of justice

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed these applications and granted the certificates under Art. 133 1  c  and that is how these appeals come before us.

issues.text: Whether the applications were maintainable under s. 20 of the Minimum Wages Act

anchor.surface_text: The managers of the estates contested these applications mainly on two grounds viz.,  1  that the applications were not maintainable under s. 20 of the Act,

issues.text: Whether there was a fixed workload or task in respect of plucking for earning daily basic wages before the introduction of the minimum wages

anchor.surface_text: and  2  that there was nofixed workload or task in respect of plucking for earning daily basic wages before the introduction of the minimum wages. The Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, who was the authority appointed under the Act to hear the claims arising out of the payment of less than the minimum rates of wages to these labourers,

issues.text: Whether the notification dated March 11, 1952, fixed only a minimum time rate and nothing more
Whether the claims of the labourers arise out of payment of less than the minimum rates of wages and fall within s. 20 of the Act
Whether the Supreme Court should interfere with the High Court's dismissal of the writ petitions under Art. 226 seeking certiorari against the Deputy Commissioner's orders

anchor.surface_text: The matters do not come to us by way of appeal directly from the orders of the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar. They were the subject, in the first instance, of proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Assam. Proceedings by way of certiorari are not of course .  Vide Halsburys Laws of England,

arguments.claim: The applications were not maintainable under s. 20 of the Minimum Wages Act

anchor.surface_text: The managers of the estates contested these applications mainly on two grounds viz.,  1  that the applications were not maintainable under s. 20 of the Act,

arguments.court_reasoning: Court does not decide jurisdiction directly but declines to interfere due to concurrent findings and procedural reasons

arguments.claim: There was no fixed workload or task in respect of plucking for earning daily basic wages before the introduction of the minimum wages

anchor.surface_text: and  2  that there was nofixed workload or task in respect of plucking for earning daily basic wages before the introduction of the minimum wages.

arguments.court_reasoning: Evidence showed existing task of 16/12 seers; notification recognized existing tasks

arguments.claim: The notification dated March 11, 1952, fixed only a minimum time rate and nothing more
arguments.court_reasoning: Minimum wages related to existing workload/task; notification directed continuance of existing tasks

arguments.claim: The continuance of existing workload or task was only to prevent employers from increasing it, not related to basic wages
arguments.court_reasoning: Basic wages calculated on existing task basis at 6 ps per seer; increase intended while maintaining task

arguments.claim: This is not a case of payment of less than the minimum rates of wages; claims are for extra wages over basic, not within s.20
arguments.court_reasoning: Court expressly does not decide jurisdiction question

arguments.claim: Authority under s.20 has no jurisdiction for complicated questions of law/fact requiring evidence and construction of notification
arguments.court_reasoning: Court avoids deciding due to concurrent findings

arguments.claim: Existing workload/task of 16 seers for males and 12 for females entitled basic wages + extra at 6 ps per seer excess

anchor.surface_text: Prior to the fixation of the minimum wages ... the labourers engaged in plucking tea leave, in these tea estates used to be paid basic wages for male labourers at as. 8/- per day

arguments.court_reasoning: Concurrent findings by Dep Comm and High Court; evidence from Hazira Moharers; notification implies

arguments.claim: Applications maintainable under s.20 as case of payment less than minimum wages

anchor.surface_text: As regards the first objection, he held that, if the applicants version was true there was a clear case of payment of less than the minimum wages fixed by the Government

arguments.qualifiers: if the applicants version was true
arguments.court_reasoning: SC does not decide but endorses merits

arguments.claim: There was workload/task of 16/12 seers for basic wages pre-notification; basic min wages related to that + extra

anchor.surface_text: As regards the second objection, he came to the conclusion on the evidence recorded before him that there was a work-load or task of 16 seers for male labourers and 12 seers

arguments.claim: Notification fixed minimum wages related to existing task, not pure time rate; extra for excess
Labourers entitled to basic min wages for existing task of 16/12 seers + extra at 6 ps/seer
No need to decide jurisdiction under s.20 as concurrent findings on merits; matters pending long
No interference via certiorari as supervisory jurisdiction; no failure of justice; concurrent merits findings

holdings.text: We are, therefore, of opinion that what was fixed by the notification was not merely a minimum time rate irrespective of the existing work-load or task which used to be performed by the labourers- but was a minimum wage which, though fixed for time work, was necessarily related to the work-load or task then being performed by these labourers so that whatever extra work was done by the labourers in excess of the existing work-load or task of plucking 16 seers of tea leaves in the case of male labourers and 12 seers of tea leaves in the case of female labourers had to be paid for in accordance with the practice then prevailing, whether it was based on agreement or ticca or custom, at the rate of 6 ps. per seer.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification directed continuance of existing tasks; basic wages increased from prior rate of 6 ps per seer for 16/12 seers task while maintaining same task and extra payment practice; rejecting pure time rate interpretation.

holdings.text: The conclusions reached in this behalf both by the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, and the High Court are, therefore, correct and cannot be challenged.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent factual findings on existence of pre-notification task of 16/12 seers supported by evidence of Hazira Moharers and implied in notification.

holdings.text: We do not propose to decide this question of jurisdiction as in the instant cases we have, in addition to the determination of the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, the adjudication of the main disputes between the parties by the High Court itself.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent merits adjudication by lower authorities; long pendency since 1952; no useful purpose served by interference despite possible jurisdictional issues.

holdings.text: the labourers are entitled to be paid the basic wages of as. 12/-per day,for male labourers and as. 11/- per day for female labourers for the work.load or task of plucking 16 seers and 12 seers of green leaves respectively and-- they are -entitled to extra wages for every seer of green leaves plucked by. them I over and above these quantities of 16 seers and 12 ,seers respectively, at the. computation of 6 Ps. per seer.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorsement of concurrent findings applying notification to facts; basic wages for specified task plus extra as per prevailing practice.

holdings.text: We are of opinion that, having regard to the merits which have been concurrently found in favour of the respondents both by the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, and the High Court, we should decline to interfere. This being the point of substance which has been decided in favour of the respondents, we are of the opinion that the appeals are liable to be dismissed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Certiorari is supervisory not appellate; no failure of justice shown; concurrent findings on merits; cites Halsbury on discretionary nature.

anchor.surface_text: This being the point of substance which has been decided in favour of the respondents, we are of the opinion that the appeals are liable to be dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed; court declines to interfere with orders of Deputy Commissioner and High Court directing payment of basic minimum wages for specified task quantities and extra wages at 6 ps. per seer in excess
